As I've said, we're just trying some things, and seeing what works and what=
 doesn't.=C2=A0 I don't understand why people run their own experiments sep=
arate from yours upsets you so.

You said below "I think much of the parano=
rmal depends on expectations, and if one 
expects to test this stuff with n=
o results, that's what they get."=C2=A0 So then, if participants expect to =
get the right answers, by your comment, it should work.


You said: "these =
pompus 
skeptics that accept no evidence".=C2=A0 It seems like you've start=
ed calling me names again, but I am accepting all the evidence these experi=
ments, show, whether positive or negative. You are not accepting the eviden=
ce the experiments are showing.

If you have other experiments, or changes =
to the current conditions, I am happy to try to accommodate them.=C2=A0 But=
 just calling people names from the sidelines doesn't really add anything t=
o the research, doesn't really advance any of your points, and certainly do=
esn't reflect well on your claims

Rj



--- On Wed, 8/4/10, purplespacefri=
end <purplealiengirl@...> wrote:

From: purplespacefriend <purplealie=
ngirl@...>

To: EVP-ITC=
@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, August 4, 2010, 8:07 AM







=C2=A0



=
  


    
      
      
       Y'all don't get it! Paranormal stuff does no=
t seem to work on demand like this. Much has to do with expectation, and if=
 the one doing the testing expects no results, that's usually what comes of=
 these tests. The only result is making the participants look like idiots. =
Many skeptics pull this testing crap, and they are notorious for changing t=
he rules and conditions to make all things paranormal go away. 



I said t=
his at the start of this crap that there was only one result possible, to m=
ake all paticipants look foolish for believing in ghosts. 



People like t=
his will not allow themselves to hear EVPs, as they can't trust their heari=
ng, and are convinced by other eskeptics that that it's all the brain fooli=
ng itself, and somehow their hearing is superior to everyone else's. 



I =
think much of the paranormal depends on expectations, and if one expects to=
 test this stuff with no results, that's what they get. There is a certain =
openness and allowing that is required.



Everyone of these test is just m=
ore ammo for the skeptics that want the world to conform to what some autho=
rity figure says is ok the think about. 



I've had it with this group, it=
's not bad enough to get these pompus skeptics that accept no evidence, but=
 then there's the one's the know so much better that the boxes can't work, =
despite the fact that thousands use the method and get two way, verifiable =
communications. Not good enouhg, they want Slimmer from Ghost Busters to ju=
mp out of the box and slap them one the side of the head.  



Alot of verb=
age that be ignored anyway. It either has to be all TAPS, or all debunking.=
 



F-S



--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "rasterer" <rasterer@...> wrote=
:

>

> 

> Thanks to everyone who participated in Experiment 3.

> 

> On =
Friday, 7/30/2010 I placed an object on top of my computer monitor, right i=
n front of me, and left it there until noon Denver time on Monday, 8/2/2010=
.   This experiment asked for participants to determine what that object wa=
s. Vague or partial answers won't be counted (for example, just giving a co=
lor, shape, size,  what it's made of, etc): we're looking for what it is. A=
nswers anyone reveals after noon Denver time Monday won't count.  Participa=
nts could use their ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or any other means they cho=
se.  

> 

> In order to keep me honest, I took a picture of the object at =
the start of the experiment and loaded it to the Files section (RJ folder) =
of this group.  The idea with this file is that you could download it at th=
e beginning of the experiment and 'keep it safe' on your computer. Then at =
the end of the experiment, I would post the password so you could reveal th=
e contents of the file. That way, you were in control of the original image=
 during the entire time, not me.  

> 

> Passworded pdf: http://tech.group=
s.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ20100730.pdf

> 

> The password for t=
hat file is: 867530Nieine

> 

> So to the results:

> 

> Number of partic=
ipants: 2

> Total tries: 3

> Ambiguous answers: 0

> Correct answers: 0

=
> 

> Object: A Pot

> Object picture: http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/E=
VP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ20100730.jpg

> 

> 

> If anyone has any observations, c=
omments, or ideas for improvement, let me know. Again, thanks to everyone w=
ho participated in this experiment.

>
